bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Florence M. Read, April 1, 1922

div1.p: Carter feels that there is no danger to the coast from any yellow fever east of the Peruvian mountains due to distance, population size, and a paucity of water storage.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Florence M. Read, April 1, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
, D. C.
April 1, 1922.
Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of March 30th., enclosing excerpts
from Hanson's letter of March 1st. and March 2nd., I would say that
I don't know where the Chanchamayo Valley is, nor do I know whether the
Central Railroad of which he speaks is the one that goes up from Mollendo
to Cuzco, well to the east of the Cordillera, or the extension of the
old Aroyo Railroad from Lima. I think the latter; am sure of it.

If in this valley, as is true of, I think, all of Peru east of the Andes (except
possibly on the Amazon) the population is small, scattered quite station-
ary and with so much rain that it is not necessary to do much stowing of
water, unquestionably yellow fever would last but a little while in any
district of this region--i. e. would eliminate itself spontaneously by
failure of the human host. Nevertheless, knowing nothing of the Chan-
chamayo region or the ease and frequency of communication therefrom to
the infectable parts of the Coast, I really have not data enough on which
to have definite advice. My impression--it is only an impression, of course--
is that there is extremely little chance of yellow fever crossing to
the Coast from a focus east of the Cordillera:

1/ Because such a focus, if at all close to the Cordillera, would
last but a short time, and

2/ Because of the infrequency of communication and the time consum-
consum-
2.
ed in going across. We have no evidence that it has ever done so--indeed,
are quite sure that it has not. I should think. too, that from Lima south
would be little liable to infection after--say--May 1st. of this year. It
is improbable that yellow fever succeeding in crossingexisting across the Andes would last--
say--from February 1st.--which probably would be the date of any that Hanson
had heard of--to next October.

However, I would suggest that if Chanchamayo is readily accessible
to Dr. Hanson, that he make further inquiries from as close as he can get
by railroad and if, in his judgment, it seems advisable--a personal investi-
gation.

Frankly, I do not believe this to be necessary, but you are finish-
ing up a rather important job on the West Coast and I would feel like taking
Hanson's opinion on the matter as to its advisibility.

It is fair to repeat that we know of no cases in which yellow fever
has crossed the Cordillera and, although means of communication are much
better than they used to be, yet the winter season is almost on us and also
I profoundly doubt whether there is, or has been, any yellow fever in this
section.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
